title: 103_hr5098
content: The "Fort Peck Tribes-Montana Compact Act of 1994" approves and ratifies the Fort Peck Indian Tribes-Montana Compact. It also confirms agreements related to the use of water rights. The Fort Peck Indian Tribes may enter into Water Agreements for the delivery, use, or transfer of water rights confirmed in the Tribes by the Fort Peck Indian Tribes-Montana Compact, for up to 50 years. The Fort Peck Indian Tribes can enter into Water Agreements allowing the delivery, use, or transfer of water rights for up to 50 years, with approval from the Secretary within specific timeframes. The Fort Peck Indian Tribes can enter into Water Agreements for up to 50 years, with approval from the Secretary within specific timeframes. Parties can enforce the agreement provisions as per section 1361 of title 28, United States Code. The Fort Peck Indian Tribes can enter into Water Agreements for up to 50 years, with approval from the Secretary within specific timeframes. Parties can enforce the agreement provisions as per section 1361 of title 28, United States Code, and any other applicable Federal law. The Department of the Interior must maintain confidentiality of any information related to the terms and conditions of a Water Agreement. The Department of the Interior must treat information related to Water Agreements as privileged Tribes' proprietary information. Tribes are limited in entering agreements despite the Fort Peck Indian Tribes-Montana Compact. The Tribes' financial benefits from Water Agreements are considered privileged information. Despite limitations, the Tribes cannot authorize the use of tribal water rights outside the Basin. An "Assiniboine and Sioux Tribes Economic Recovery Fund" is established for economic development. The Fort Peck Indian Tribes-Montana Compact prohibits the Tribes from allowing the use of tribal water rights outside the Basin. An "Assiniboine and Sioux Tribes Economic Recovery Fund" is created for economic development, funded by a percentage of receipts from the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin Project. The Secretary of the Treasury deposits 10% of receipts from the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin Project into a fund, capped at $50,000,000. Interest accrued on the deposits is placed in a separate account for use without fiscal restrictions. The Secretary of the Treasury deposits 10% of receipts from the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin Project into a fund capped at $50,000,000. Interest accrued on the deposits is placed in a separate account for unrestricted use by the Secretary of the Interior for tribal economic development. The Secretary of the Treasury deposits 10% of receipts from the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin Project into a fund capped at $50,000,000 for tribal economic development. The fund is used for tribal economic development, acquisition of lands, and improvement of acquired lands, subject to the approval of the Secretary of the Interior. Amounts deposited in the fund are nonreimbursable and nonreturnable. The fund, capped at $50,000,000, is used for tribal economic development through the acquisition and improvement of lands within the Reservation. Payments from the fund are nonreimbursable and nonreturnable, and do not affect Federal services or programs for the Tribes or their members. No payments under this Act will reduce or deny Federal services for Tribes or their members. Payments are not subject to income tax or affect power rates. Funds cannot be distributed on a per capita basis. The United States waives claims in exchange for fulfilling obligations. The Tribes' funds under this Act will not be distributed on a per capita basis. In exchange for the United States fulfilling its obligations, the Tribes waive any existing claims related to water rights settled by the Fort Peck Indian Tribes-Montana Compact. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The Fort Peck Indian Tribes-Montana Compact refers to the water rights agreement ratified in 1985. The Reservation is defined as the Fort Peck Indian Reservation. The Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Fort Peck Indian Tribes-Montana Compact ratified in 1985 defines key terms such as Reservation, Secretary, Tribes, tribal water right, and Fund. The term "Tribes" refers to the Assiniboine and Sioux Tribes of the Fort Peck Indian Reservation. The term "tribal water right" is defined in the Fort Peck-Montana Compact. The "Fund" is the Assiniboine and Sioux Tribes Economic Recovery Fund.
